head.title: Ruling Gives Juries More Say In Personal-Injury Lawsuits

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New Jersey

hedline.hl1: Ruling Gives Juries More Say In Personal-Injury Lawsuits

abstract.p: New Jersey State Supreme Court rules jury, not judge, should decide what constitutes disfigurement or loss of bodily function in personal-injury suit; decision, which overturns appeals court ruling, will let more claims advance to trial stage (M)1

block.p: In a decision that could be costly for the state and for local governments, the New Jersey State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that it should be up to a jury, not a judge, to decide what constitutes disfigurement or loss of bodily function in a personal-injury lawsuit.

The decision, which overturned an appellate ruling, will allow more claims to advance to the trial stage. Thus, it could add to the millions of dollars a year in jury awards already financed by taxpayers and prompt higher municipal insurance premiums, experts say.

In a decision that could be costly for the state and for local governments, the New Jersey State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that it should be up to a jury, not a judge, to decide what constitutes disfigurement or loss of bodily function in a personal-injury lawsuit.

The decision, which overturned an appellate ruling, will allow more claims to advance to the trial stage. Thus, it could add to the millions of dollars a year in jury awards already financed by taxpayers and prompt higher municipal insurance premiums, experts say.

''Is this going to have an impact?'' asked William J. Kearns, general counsel for the New Jersey League of Municipalities. ''Of course it is, on all kinds of public entities: the state, counties, school districts, anything that comes under the Tort Claims Act,'' the law governing such claims.

The decision stems from a suit by a 70-year-old social worker, Catherine Gilhooly, who broke her kneecap and tore ligaments in her right knee on Dec. 31, 1994, when she slipped after walking on a wet floor at the Union County Jail, where she had gone to see a client.

The trial judge, Leonard S. Sachar of Superior Court in Elizabeth, dismissed Ms. Gilhooly's suit against the county, ruling that, following surgery to implant metal pins and a cable, she could walk again and had returned to work. The scar she was left with, while visible, did not significantly alter her appearance, the trial judge said.

The Supreme Court disagreed. In a majority opinion written by Justice Virginia Long, the court ruled that ''there is no question Ms. Gilhooly suffered a permanent injury.'' In assessing the scar, Justice Long wrote, ''the judge erroneously weighted the evidence and, applying his own personal standard, determined the merits of the case.'' The court sent the case back to the trial court for a jury trial to be scheduled for sometime within 90 days.

During arguments before the Supreme Court in May, the county's lawyer, John J. Kane, tried to establish that, because the scar did not have an impact on Ms. Gilhooly's social or professional life, it was not grounds for a disfigurement award. Her lawyer, Richard A. Dunne, said that argument now has been rejected, which essentially lowers the threshold for disfigurement claims. ''If the law's applied across the board,'' Mr. Dunne said, ''it shouldn't matter whether you're a 25-year-old model or a 70-year-old social worker.''
